newsitem.title: USA: U.S. corporate bond supply looms large over market.
newsitem.headline: U.S. corporate bond supply looms large over market.

text.p: U.S. corporations continue to line up to bring deals to market as demand for corporate paper persists and issuers captialize on lower rates to finance debt, dealers said.

Among deals expected to come to market Tuesday is the Philip Morris $500 million 10-year A2/A rated note offering via Lehman Brothers. Price talk on the issue is 76 to 78 basis points over comparable Treasuries.
Another expected to tap the market is Mead with a $550 million multi-tranche debt deal, syndicate sources said.
The four-part Mead deal is expected to consist of the following maturities, syndicate sources said:
--20-year with price talk of 65 basis points over Treasuries
--40-year with price talk of 40 basis points over Treasuries
--50-year with price talk seen in low 80s.
"There's a lot of paper being put away," said one high-grade syndicate ssource. "We just have to wait and see how these upcoming deals perform and that will set the tone."
Mead's 40-year tranche is puttable in the 10th year, sources added.
Also on the new issue agenda is a $700 million multi-tranche investment-grade corporate bond offering from Sherwin-Williams via Salomon Brothers, sources said.
The company will sell $100 million three-year notes, $100 million five-year notes and $200 million 10-year bonds in a public deal.
The second part of the deal, which will be sold privately via a 144A offering, consist of $150 million in 30-year bonds and $150 million in 100-year bonds, sources added.
Looking ahead, sources said Union Carbide Corp was getting set to bring a $250 million 30-year capital securities deal, callable in 10 years, as early as this week.

International CableTel Inc was expected to tap the private placement market with $300 million in 10-year 144A senior notes and $100 million in 144A preferreds due 2009 via Donaldson Lufkin and Jenrette Securities, sources said.
Also, TCI Satellite Entertainment was preparing to bring its $350 million two-part debut debt offering via joint lead managers Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities and Merrill Lynch.
